articles.snippet: Fifty people were killed in shootings at two mosques in Christchurch, New Zealand, on Friday. Officials said a 28-year-old man had been charged with murder.

headline.main: Jacinda Ardern Consoles Families After New Zealand Shooting

articles.snippet: The police said four people had been taken into custody after the attack in New Zealand.
articles.lead_paragraph: Forty-nine people were killed in shootings at two mosques in central Christchurch, New Zealand, on Friday, in a terrorist attack that Prime Minister Jacinda Ardern described as “an extraordinary and unprecedented act of violence.”
articles.abstract: The police said four people had been taken into custody after the attack in New Zealand.

headline.main: Christchurch Shooting Live Updates: 49 Are Dead After 2 Mosques Are Hit

articles.snippet: The terrorist attack in New Zealand is shocking on every level — and feels like a first for how unmistakably online it was.
articles.lead_paragraph: Before entering a mosque in Christchurch, New Zealand, the site of one of the deadliest mass murders in the country’s history, a gunman paused to endorse a YouTube star in a video that appeared to capture the shooting.
articles.abstract: The terrorist attack in New Zealand is shocking on every level — and feels like a first for how unmistakably online it was.

headline.main: A Mass Murder of, and for, the Internet
headline.print_headline: A Shooting Disturbingly Rooted in the Internet

articles.snippet: The police said a man in his late 20s was arrested and charged with murder but declined to identify him. Three others were also in custody, but it was unclear if they were involved.
articles.lead_paragraph: WELLINGTON, New Zealand — At least 49 people were killed at two mosques in Christchurch, New Zealand, on Friday, in a horrific and methodical afternoon slaughter, part of which was broadcast live on the internet after the publication of a white supremacist manifesto online.
articles.abstract: The police said a man in his late 20s was arrested and charged with murder but declined to identify him. Three others were also in custody, but it was unclear if they were involved.

headline.main: Christchurch Mosque Shootings Were Partly Streamed on Facebook
headline.print_headline: New Zealand Left in Shock As 2 Mosques Are Attacked

byline.original: By Charlotte Graham-McLay, Austin Ramzy and Daniel Victor

articles.snippet: The gunman in the Christchurch mosque shootings shared a racist manifesto online and posted live video of his attack on Facebook. We spoke to terrorism experts about why this matters.
articles.lead_paragraph: The gunman in the Christchurch mosque shootings shared a racist manifesto online and posted live video of his attack on Facebook. We spoke to terrorism experts about why this matters.
articles.abstract: The gunman in the Christchurch mosque shootings shared a racist manifesto online and posted live video of his attack on Facebook. We spoke to terrorism experts about why this matters.

headline.main: Terror in Real Time: How the New Zealand Gunman Used Social Media

articles.snippet: Several charities sought donations to help the victims’ families and those wounded in the attack on two New Zealand mosques to rebuild their lives.
articles.lead_paragraph: As Muslims in Christchurch, New Zealand, grieved after attacks on two mosques killed at least 50 people and injured dozens more, several charities sought donations to help the wounded and the victims’ families rebuild their lives.
articles.abstract: Several charities sought donations to help the victims’ families and those wounded in the attack on two New Zealand mosques to rebuild their lives.

headline.main: How to Help the Victims of the Christchurch Shootings

articles.snippet: Prime Minister Jacinda Ardern had made clear that lawmakers will look at a range of options, from gun buybacks to restrictions on magazines for semiautomatic rifles.
articles.lead_paragraph: CHRISTCHURCH, New Zealand — When the prime minister announced plans to ban semiautomatic rifles following Friday’s mass shootings, it seemed to be the bold response that many New Zealanders wanted — until the country’s attorney general backpedaled almost immediately and said that might not be the government’s final decision.
articles.abstract: Prime Minister Jacinda Ardern had made clear that lawmakers will look at a range of options, from gun buybacks to restrictions on magazines for semiautomatic rifles.

headline.main: After Mosque Massacre, New Zealand Has Its Gun-Debate Moment
headline.print_headline: New Zealand Faces a Crossroads on Gun Control

articles.abstract: New Zealand grappled with grief and horror on Sunday, as the death toll rose to 50, two days after a terrorist attack at two mosques in the city of Christchurch.

headline.main: More Than a Dozen Victims in Critical Condition After New Zealand Shootings

articles.snippet: Prime Minister Jacinda Ardern ordered an inquiry into what the government “could or should have known” about the suspect in the attack on two mosques in Christchurch.
articles.lead_paragraph: DUNEDIN, New Zealand — The gun enthusiast with light brown hair and an Australian accent did not stand out among the 100 or so members of the Bruce Rifle Club, who practiced shooting at a range in a forest in southern New Zealand.
articles.abstract: Prime Minister Jacinda Ardern ordered an inquiry into what the government “could or should have known” about the suspect in the attack on two mosques in Christchurch.

headline.main: New Zealand Asks What It Could Have Done Differently as Portrait of Shooting Suspect Emerges
headline.print_headline: After Massacre, New Zealand Asks What It Could Have Done Differently

articles.snippet: Fifty people were killed when a gunman stormed two mosques in Christchurch, New Zealand, and opened fire on worshippers. Among the dead were students, athletes, engineers and an aspiring pilot.
articles.lead_paragraph: One was a dairy farmer. Another aspired to be a pilot. One was an elder known for helping newcomers. Another was a teenager who called his mother when the shooting started. The 50 people slaughtered by a gunman at two Christchurch mosques last week spanned a range of backgrounds. Here is what we know about them.
articles.abstract: Fifty people were killed when a gunman stormed two mosques in Christchurch, New Zealand, and opened fire on worshippers. Among the dead were students, athletes, engineers and an aspiring pilot.

headline.main: The New Zealand Shooting Victims Spanned Generations and Nationalities
headline.print_headline: Portraits Emerge Of Lives Cut Short By Gunman’s Hate

articles.snippet: New Zealand’s prime minister made the announcement less than a week after the Christchurch massacre. Mass shootings have also had a mobilizing effect in Australia, Britain, Canada and Germany.
articles.lead_paragraph: It took New Zealand just six days to announce an immediate plan to change to the nation’s gun policy after a gunman killed 50 people at two mosques in Christchurch last week.
articles.abstract: New Zealand’s prime minister made the announcement less than a week after the Christchurch massacre. Mass shootings have also had a mobilizing effect in Australia, Britain, Canada and Germany.

headline.main: New Zealand Took 6 Days to Plan New Gun Laws. Here’s How Other Countries Reacted to Shootings.

articles.snippet: As the first six victims of the Christchurch mosque shootings were laid to rest, some affected families were still waiting to learn the fate of their loved ones.
articles.lead_paragraph: CHRISTCHURCH, New Zealand — Azaam Afaan did not want to be late. The first funeral since Friday’s terrorist attack was about to begin, and though he had no idea who was being buried, he just knew he needed to participate.
articles.abstract: As the first six victims of the Christchurch mosque shootings were laid to rest, some affected families were still waiting to learn the fate of their loved ones.

headline.main: ‘So Heartbreaking’: Funerals Begin for New Zealand Attack Victims
headline.print_headline: Burying Victims of a Massacre in a City Full of Emptiness

byline.original: By Damien Cave and Charlotte Graham-McLay

articles.snippet: The killing of 50 people in New Zealand last week seems to be the most extreme example of a mass shooter using the internet as part of his arsenal of destruction and hate. We look at how this affected our calculations around how to cover the attac...
articles.lead_paragraph: Sadly, The Times has covered a lot of shootings. But the killing of 50 people at mosques in Christchurch, New Zealand, on Friday by a gunman intent on using the tools of the internet as weapons in his fight raised a number of new issues for our newsroom.
articles.abstract: The killing of 50 people in New Zealand last week seems to be the most extreme example of a mass shooter using the internet as part of his arsenal of destruction and hate. We look at how this affected our calculations around how to cover the attack.

headline.main: The New Zealand Attack Posed New Challenges for Journalists. Here Are the Decisions The Times Made.

articles.snippet: The country’s leaders want a solution, not just the problem, to become a global phenomenon.
articles.lead_paragraph: CHRISTCHURCH, New Zealand — The ad hoc memorial at the police cordon spread out across a wide area. Within a few hours of the terrorist attack that stole the lives of 50 people at two mosques here, there was a mountain of flowers and handwritten messages filled with anguish.
articles.abstract: The country’s leaders want a solution, not just the problem, to become a global phenomenon.

headline.main: New Zealand Confronts an American Export: Mass Shootings

articles.snippet: The charges came as Prime Minister Jacinda Ardern vowed to investigate the role that social media companies played in mosque massacres last week.
articles.lead_paragraph: CHRISTCHURCH, New Zealand — A lone white supremacist is the suspect in the Christchurch mosque killings. But under New Zealand law, many others could face charges for spreading or perhaps even possessing all or part of the 17-minute Facebook Live video streamed by the killer as he methodically shot the victims.
articles.abstract: The charges came as Prime Minister Jacinda Ardern vowed to investigate the role that social media companies played in mosque massacres last week.

headline.main: Spreading the Mosque Shooting Video Is a Crime in New Zealand
headline.print_headline: Where Sharing Violent Videos Is Against Law

articles.snippet: An incorrect name was listed on a court document charging the suspect with murder, but legal experts said the mistake would not impede prosecution in the mass shooting.
articles.lead_paragraph: CHRISTCHURCH, New Zealand — The suspected gunman in last week’s attack on two mosques in Christchurch, New Zealand, was charged with murder for the death of one victim — but the police announced on Thursday that that supposed victim was in fact alive.
articles.abstract: An incorrect name was listed on a court document charging the suspect with murder, but legal experts said the mistake would not impede prosecution in the mass shooting.

headline.main: New Zealand Police Listed Wrong Person as Killed in Mosque Shooting
headline.print_headline: Listed Victim Wasn’t Killed,  Officials Say

articles.snippet: How to curb the exposure of videos like that of the shootings in New Zealand.
articles.lead_paragraph: In “We’re Asking the Wrong Questions of YouTube and Facebook After New Zealand,” Charlie Warzel wrote about the online impact of the video streamed allegedly by the gunman during the shootings in Christchurch and the need for social media and tech companies to take more responsibility for the content posted by extremists on their platforms.
articles.abstract: How to curb the exposure of videos like that of the shootings in New Zealand.

headline.main: Can We Block a Shooter’s Viral Aspirations?

articles.snippet: Prime Minister Jacinda Arden told mourners in Christchurch that “the world has been stuck in a vicious cycle of extremism breeding extremism” that “must end.”
articles.lead_paragraph: CHRISTCHURCH, New Zealand — Lamenting that “the world has been stuck in a vicious cycle of extremism breeding extremism,” Prime Minister Jacinda Ardern of New Zealand said at a national memorial service for the Christchurch attack victims on Friday that the dangerous cycle “must end.”
articles.abstract: Prime Minister Jacinda Arden told mourners in Christchurch that “the world has been stuck in a vicious cycle of extremism breeding extremism” that “must end.”

headline.main: New Zealand Memorial Service for Shooting Victims Draws Thousands
headline.print_headline: Hard Questions and Celebration of Survival at Service

articles.snippet: No established democracies have ever come as close to applying such sweeping restrictions as Australia and New Zealand are considering in the wake of the Christchurch mosque shootings.
articles.lead_paragraph: SYDNEY, Australia — What if live-streaming required a government permit, and videos could only be broadcast online after a seven-second delay?
articles.abstract: No established democracies have ever come as close to applying such sweeping restrictions as Australia and New Zealand are considering in the wake of the Christchurch mosque shootings.

headline.main: Countries Want to Ban ‘Weaponized’ Social Media. What Would That Look Like?

articles.snippet: The suspect, who appeared in court via video link from prison, also faces 39 counts of attempted murder.
articles.lead_paragraph: CHRISTCHURCH, New Zealand — Brenton Harrison Tarrant, the Australian man accused of killing 50 people last month at two mosques in Christchurch, New Zealand, appeared in court on Friday via video link from prison to face dozens of additional charges.
articles.abstract: The suspect, who appeared in court via video link from prison, also faces 39 counts of attempted murder.

headline.main: New Zealand Shooting Suspect Is Charged With 50 Counts of Murder
headline.print_headline: In New Zealand, Suspect Charged In 50 Murders

articles.snippet: Prime Minister Jacinda Ardern of New Zealand said that the man, a Turkish national, had been in an intensive care unit in a Christchurch hospital since the shooting seven weeks ago.
articles.lead_paragraph: WELLINGTON, New Zealand — The death toll from the terrorist attack on two mosques in Christchurch, New Zealand, in March rose to 51 on Thursday, when a man wounded during the shooting died in a hospital.
articles.abstract: Prime Minister Jacinda Ardern of New Zealand said that the man, a Turkish national, had been in an intensive care unit in a Christchurch hospital since the shooting seven weeks ago.

headline.main: Death Toll in New Zealand Mosque Shootings Rises to 51

articles.snippet: When 51 people were killed in New Zealand, the suspect broadcast it live on Facebook. The massacre led to a global call to combat the spread of violent content.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — When 51 people were killed in Christchurch, New Zealand, in March, the suspect, an Australian man, broadcast the attack live on Facebook. The video spread across the internet.
articles.abstract: When 51 people were killed in New Zealand, the suspect broadcast it live on Facebook. The massacre led to a global call to combat the spread of violent content.

headline.main: Facebook Restricts Live Streaming After New Zealand Shooting
headline.print_headline: Facebook Moves to Police  Content on Its Live Service

byline.original: By Cade Metz and Adam Satariano

articles.snippet: From Pittsburgh to Christchurch, the men who have carried out deadly shootings cite the same fear: the replacement of white people.
articles.lead_paragraph: From Pittsburgh to Christchurch, and now El Paso, white men accused of carrying out deadly mass shootings have cited the same paranoid fear: the extinction of the white race.
articles.abstract: From Pittsburgh to Christchurch, the men who have carried out deadly shootings cite the same fear: the replacement of white people.

headline.main: The El Paso Screed, and the Racist Doctrine Behind It
headline.print_headline: A False Dogma of Racism,  Paranoia and Grievances

articles.snippet: The man accused of killing 51 people in a terrorist attack on two mosques in New Zealand will be tried in the city where the shooting occurred, after his legal team withdrew a bid for a new venue.
articles.lead_paragraph: CHRISTCHURCH, New Zealand — The Australian man accused of killing 51 people and wounding dozens more in a terrorist attack on two mosques in New Zealand will be tried in the city of Christchurch, where the shooting occurred, after he told his legal team on Thursday to withdraw his application to have it moved to another city.
articles.abstract: The man accused of killing 51 people in a terrorist attack on two mosques in New Zealand will be tried in the city where the shooting occurred, after his legal team withdrew a bid for a new venue.

headline.main: Christchurch Shooting Suspect Drops Bid to Move Trial to Auckland
